title: (x) Which? Magazine serif face - Which (custom typeface by Nick Cooke) {James}
content: anybody know what this font is - I see it everywhere ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050524123808im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/69376.jpg) Most recently "which?" magazine has used it - it also has a light version
author: monkeyben

comments.content:
FF Sheriff is similar, especially in the treatment of the lower case serifs:   
   
 [http://www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=FF.10466.5.17&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=BIG+Winner&sampleSize=48](http://web.archive.org/web/20050524123808/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=FF.10466.5.17&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=BIG+Winner&sampleSize=48)

Which? Magazine (which is the same as your sample I believe) uses is a custom-designed font family simply called Which. There is a serif (like the sample ) and a sans in a variety of weights. I don't know who designed it.   
   
Marc's suggestion of FF Sheriff is an excellent one since the lowercase looks nearly identical. I wouldn't be surprised if it was the same designer.   
   
Here are samples:   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050524123808im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/69475.jpg)   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20050524123808im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/69476.jpg)

I did it for Which? magazine, so only they can use it. Sorry!   
   
I didn't do FF Sheriff.   
   
PS. James - how did you get these samples. Looks like somebody has been manual kerning on the serif; a bit tight between m and o.
